{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2010 |Team=South Carolina Gamecocks |Image=South Carolina Gamecocks wordmark.svg |ImageSize=150 |Conference=Southeastern Conference |Division=Eastern Division |ShortConference=SEC |Record=9â5 |ConfRecord=5â3 |CoachRank=22 |APRank=22 |HeadCoach= [[Steve Spurrier]] |DefCoach= [[Ellis Johnson (American football coach)|Ellis Johnson]] |OScheme= Multiple |DScheme= 4-2-5 |StadiumArena=[[Williams-Brice Stadium]]
(c. 80,250, grass) |Champion= SEC Eastern Division Champions |ConfChamp = [[2010 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship]] vs. [[2010 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] |ConfChampResult = L 17â56 |BowlTourney =[[2010 Chick-fil-A Bowl|Chick-fil-A Bowl]] vs. [[2010 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] |BowlTourneyResult =L 17â26 }} {{2010 SEC football standings}} The '''2010 South Carolina Gamecocks football team''' represented the [[University of South Carolina]] in the [[2010 NCAA Division I FBS football season]]. The team's head football coach was [[Steve Spurrier]], who was in his sixth season at USC. The Gamecocks played their home games at [[Williams-Brice Stadium]] in [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]], [[South Carolina]] and were members of the Eastern Division of the [[Southeastern Conference]]. The Gamecocks finished the season 9â5, 5â3 in SEC play to win the Eastern Division. They earned their first appearance in the [[2010 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship]] where they were defeated by [[2010 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] 17â56. They were invited to the [[2010 Chick-fil-A Bowl|Chick-fil-A Bowl]], the most lucrative bowl in the program's 116-year history, where they were defeated by [[2010 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] 17â26. ==Preseason== On April 10, 2010, the White squad defeated the Garnet squad, 21â17, in the annual Garnet & Black Spring Game, in front of a crowd of 22,000. ==Schedule== The October 9 game against Alabama played host to ESPN's [[College GameDay]], the program's 5th time hosting the popular ESPN show.[http://gamecocksonline.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/100310aaa.html ESPN's GameDay is Coming to Our City-Popular Traveling Show To Make Fifth Visit to Columbia] {{CFB Schedule Zone|Eastern Time]]}} {{cite web|url=http://www.fbschedules.com/ncaa-10/sec/2010-south-carolina-gamecocks-football-schedule.php|title=2010 South Carolina Gamecocks Football Schedule|publisher=fbschedules.com|accessdate=2010-01-02}} {{cite web|url=http://gamecocksonline.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/future-schedules.html|title=2010 South Carolina Gamecocks Football Schedule|publisher=gamecocksonlin.cstv.com|accessdate=2010-01-02}} ==Game notes== ===Southern Miss=== {{See also|2010 Southern Miss Golden Eagles football team}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Golden Eagles |R1=3 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=7 |Home='''Gamecocks''' |H1=7 |H2=17 |H3=10 |H4=7 }} Quarterback Stephen Garcia and freshman running back Marcus Lattimore each rushed for two touchdowns and USC head coach Steve Spurrier won his 18th straight season opener, 41-13 over Southern Miss. Sophomore wide receiver Alshon Jeffery also had 106 receiving yards and freshman wide receiver Ace Sanders had a 53-yard run off of a reverse. Freshman backup quarterback Connor Shaw also had a highlight, throwing his first touchdown pass as a Gamecock to wide receiver D.L. Moore. {{-}} ===Georgia=== {{See also|2010 Georgia Bulldogs football team}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#22 Bulldogs |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=3 |R4=0 |Home=#24 '''Gamecocks''' |H1=7 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=3 }} Freshman running back Marcus Lattimore carried for 182 yards and two touchdowns, as #24 South Carolina outmatched #22 Georgia, 17-6, in the SEC opener for both teams. Quarterback Stephen Garcia was 12-17 for 165 yards, with seven of his passes caught by wide receiver Alshon Jeffery, who finished with 103 yards. Lattimore had 103 yards rushing in the first half, and USC held a 228-73 edge in total yards after the first two quarters. Georgia's 6 points were the fewest allowed by Carolina to a Bulldog team since a 2-0 USC victory in 1904, and the Gamecock defense held the Bulldogs to 61 rushing yards. Head Coach Steve Spurrier won his 106th SEC game, tying him for second all-time in the conference with former Ole Miss coach Johnny Vaught. {{-}} ===Furman=== {{See also2|{{cfb link|year=2010|team=Furman Paladins}}}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Paladins |R1=0 |R2=6 |R3=7 |R4=6 |Home=#13 '''Gamecocks''' |H1=14 |H2=7 |H3=10 |H4=7 }} Stephen Garcia went 13-20 for 150 yards with two touchdown passes, and Marcus Lattimore had 19 carries for 97 yards and a touchdown to lead the #13 Gamecocks to a 38-19 win over Furman. Cornerback Stephon Gilmore sealed the game with an 80-yard interception return for touchdown in the 4th quarter. {{-}} ===Auburn=== {{See also|2010 Auburn Tigers football team}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#12 Gamecocks |R1= 14 |R2= 6 |R3= 7 |R4= 0 |Home=#17 '''Tigers''' |H1= 7 |H2= 7 |H3= 7 |H4= 14 }} {{-}} ===Alabama=== {{See also|2010 Alabama Crimson Tide football team}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#1 Crimson Tide |R1=3 |R2=6 |R3=5 |R4=7 |Home=#19 '''Gamecocks''' |H1=14 |H2=7 |H3=7 |H4=7 }} {{-}} The Gamecocks toppled Alabama at home to notch their first defeat of a top-ranked team in school history. ===Kentucky=== {{See also|2010 Kentucky Wildcats football team}} {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#10 Gamecocks |R1=14 |R2=14 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Wildcats''' |H1=0 |H2=10 |H3=7
